title: Ovo's £500m takeover of SSE's retail arm could face investigation
text:
Ovo energy's £500million takeover of SSE's household supply arm could face an investigation, the UK's competition watchdog has said.

The Competition and Markets Authority said it is considering whether the deal - which was announced last month - would result in 'a substantial lessening of competition' in the UK energy market.

The CMA is looking for comments on the proposed deal by November 6.

Competition concerns: Ovo energy wants to buy SSE's household supply arm

If it goes ahead, the takeover will see Ovo add SSE's 3.5million households to its existing 1.5million-strong customer base, catapulting it into the 'big six' league of providers and second only to British Gas.

Around 8,000 SSE energy services unit staff will also transfer to Ovo, which employs around 2,000.

The transaction was expected to be completed in late 2019 or early 2020, with SSE saying it will do everything to make sure it is a 'smooth transaction' for existing customers.

Ovo has agreed to use the SSE brand under licence for a period of time while it transfers over the bought business.

The deal came after SSE announced in May that it planned to offload its energy services division after more than 500,000 households switched to a new supplier in the year to April.

In November 2018, SSE called off a merger of its household supply arm with rival Npower, blaming 'very challenging market conditions'.

Gas and electricity suppliers have come under intense pressure in the UK following this year's introduction of the cap on standard variable tariffs, as well as increasing competition from a swathe of smaller players.
